sub_title: President at IRHA // International Rainwater Harvesting Alliance
summary:
As a senior environmental health professional operating in policy and strategy development at national and regional level in South Asia I gained a lot of exposure and experience in negotiation, clarification and facilitation of consultative processes in multi-stakeholder working environments.

Gained direct and practical experience in 
•	Teaching and training of many junior and mid-level professionals, and moderation/facilitation of international workshops and educational events 
•	Implementation of successful and sustained community water supply and sanitation programmes, and associated infrastructure for development (roads, bridges, irrigation) in Nepal and Sri Lanka, with Government and NGOs
•	Successful development and application of community management and participatory processes in urban or urbanizing areas for local improvement in water, sanitation, housing, drainage, solid waste management, etc. 
•	Promotion of affordable rainwater harvesting systems in Sri Lanka, Bangladesh and Nepal leading to large scale adoption by households for water security, and acceptance by development professionals.

Interested in providing coaching and capacity building services related to the above areas to mid-level and senior sector professionals; and in project formulation, assessment and evaluation.

Specialties: integrated water supply and environmental sanitation development programmes (national/district), NGO partnership, inclusive and rights-based programming, local capacity building, training, indoor air pollution and (renewable) energy promotion, rainwater harvesting, rural and peri-urban development planning, participatory community self-initiation and management approaches, gender, cost recovery, information management.

Advisory services and capacity building to responsible water and sanitation sector agencies in Bangladesh (6 years) and Nepal (3 years) and as regional advisor in the WHO South East Asia Regional Office (2 years), focusing on rural and small town water supply and sanitation, water safety plans and water quality monitoring,  arsenic mitigation, household water treatment and  rainwater harvesting, South Asia Conference on Sanitation, Ecosan, CLTS/SLTS; on the development of Healthy Cities; to Ministries of Health in addressing emerging environmental issues in airpollution, hazardous waste, poisoning, etc.; and on Emergency Response and Preparedness (related to public health and engineering). Provide support to regional and global activities in water quality, rainwater and water safety plans. Specific support was given to Bangladesh and Bhutan in the context of the AusAID project on Accelerating effective water, sanitation and hygiene management for health, with primary emphasis on the Asian Region (2004 to present).

profile_positions.description:
by International Development Support Services, Australia, and based in Colombo.
Task: development and implementation of an innovative, community managed, NGO partnered water supply and sanitation programme. This comprehensive development programme is demand driven, includes community mobilization and self assessment for choice of technology and affordable level of service, cost recovery and O&M management, strengthening of community based organizations and income generating activities, involvement of NGOs and the private sector as partners.

The project exceeded its targets of 900 water supply projects, covering 650'000 people, and 45'000  latrines. It assisted in the construction of sustainable WS&S facilities in 600 schools, and built 17 community operated small town schemes.

Together with IRC, established a set of regional (Asia -wide) fee-based courses on Community Water Supply and Sanitation, Hygiene Promotion, Sustainability, etc. which have run between 1995 and 2004.

CWSSP also executed the National Sector Development Programme. As a team member, took responsibility for the guidance and management of the Working Groups preparing for the first National Conference held in December 1995. Specifically, provided professional inputs in two Working Groups on "Rural, Peri-Urban Areas and Small Towns", and the "Plantation Sector" respectively.
